Authors: Gunawan A., Muchardie B.G., Kartika C.
Title: Indonesian millennial segmentation to increase behavioral intention to use language learning apps
Source title: Proceedings of 2020 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2020
Affiliations: Global Business Marketing, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; BINUS Online Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gunawan, A., Global Business Marketing, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Muchardie, B.G., BINUS Online Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kartika, C., Global Business Marketing, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The existence of language learning apps answers the needs and behavior trends of Indonesian millennial. However, the behavioral intention to use language learning apps has not been maximized. The purpose of this study is to explore the factors of Indonesian millennial behavioral intention to use language learning apps, then find out whether those factors influence Indonesian millennial behavioral intention to use language learning apps significantly, and finally identify the Indonesian millennial segmentation in language learning apps industry based on the factors of behavioral intention to use. This research uses both qualitative and quantitative methods. The results of the research show that there are 13 variables that affect Indonesian millennial behavioral intention to use language learning apps; then based on those 13 variables, 3 millennial segments are formed, namely The Thirst Learners Skill segment, The Ease-comfort Seekers segment, and The Worth-it Strivers with different characteristics. © 2020 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Behavioral intention to use; Language learning apps; Millennial segmentation
Index Keywords: Behavioral intention; Industry based; Language learning; Quantitative method; Information management

Authors: Ikhsan R.B., Saraswati L.A., Muchardie B.G., Vional, Susilo A.
Title: The determinants of students' perceived learning outcomes and satisfaction in BINUS online learning
Source title: Proceedings of 2019 5th International Conference on New Media Studies, CONMEDIA 2019
Affiliations: BINUS ONLINE Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ikhsan, R.B., BINUS ONLINE Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Saraswati, L.A., BINUS ONLINE Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Muchardie, B.G., BINUS ONLINE Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Vional, BINUS ONLINE Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Susilo, A., BINUS ONLINE Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The advancement of information technology and communication and the changing in education paradigm have influenced the process and method of learning. Online learning is one of the innovations for this recent changing paradigm. In this study, Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) is applied to examine the determinants of students' perceived learning outcomes and satisfaction in the context of university online course. Independent variables include instructor facilitation, technical support, course structure, instructor feedback, self-motivation, peer support, and interaction as potential determinants of online learning. A total of 400 BINUS Online Learning students were surveyed. The structural model result reveals that instructor facilitation, technical support, instructor feedback, and self-motivation affect the learning outcomes, and instructor facilitation, technical support, self-motivation, and peer support significantly affect the students' satisfaction. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Learning outcomes; Online learning; Students' perception; Students' satisfaction
Index Keywords: Education computing; Learning systems; Motivation; Students; Independent variables; Information technology and communications; Method of learning; Perceived learning outcomes; Structural equation modelling (SEM); Structural modeling; Students' satisfaction; Technical support; E-learning

Authors: Gunawan A., Muchardie B.G., Liawinardi K.
Title: Millennial Behavioral Intention to Adopt E-Book Using Utaut2 Model
Source title: Proceedings of 2019 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2019
Affiliations: International Marketing Program, Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Management Department, BINUS Online Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gunawan, A., International Marketing Program, Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Muchardie, B.G., Management Department, BINUS Online Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Liawinardi, K., International Marketing Program, Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The significant growth of internet users in Indonesia creates the prospect of digital book sales in Indonesia. Nevertheless, e-book sales in Indonesia are still low, which is only about 2 percent of the total books in circulation. Therefore, this study aims to determine the effect of UTAUT2 variables, personal innovativeness of IT, perceived costs and environmental consciousness in influencing the behavioral intention to adopt e-books in millennials in Jakarta simultaneously and partially done by conducting online surveys to 200 millennials in Jakarta by using SEM-PLS analysis method. The research results show that the behavioral intention to adopt e-books in millennials in Jakarta is influenced by UTAUT2 variables, perceived costs, environmental consciousness and personal innovativeness of IT simultaneously but not all partially. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: behavioral intention to adopt e-book; environmental consciousness; perceived costs; personal innovativeness of IT; UTAUT2
Index Keywords: Electronic document exchange; Electronic publishing; Information management; E-books; environmental consciousness; Perceived costs; Personal innovativeness; UTAUT2; Cost benefit analysis

Authors: Muchardie B.G., Gunawan A., Aditya B.
Title: E-Commerce Market Segmentation Based on the Antecedents of Customer Satisfaction and Customer Retention
Source title: Proceedings of 2019 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2019
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Online Learning Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Muchardie, B.G., Management Department, BINUS Online Learning Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Gunawan, A., Management Department, BINUS Online Learning Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Aditya, B., Management Department, BINUS Online Learning Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The 'grow and thrive' of e-commerce players in Indonesia and very diverse nowadays customers are causing the intense competition among the players and therefore effects on low customer retention rate. The purposes of this research are to determine the influence of psychographic factors towards customer satisfaction and customer retention in ecommerce, and secondly to identify e-commerce customer segmentation based on the psychographic and demographic factors. This is an associative-descriptive research where the data is collected through questionnaire distributed to 411 respondents with analysis methods used are Path Analysis, Cluster Analysis, and Cross-tabulation. The research result shows that all the independent factors influence customer retention through customer satisfaction, and based on those factors, there are 3 customer segments of e-commerce, i.e. The Functional Shopper, The Credibility-Matters Shopper, and The Money-Dietary Shopper. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: customer retention; customer satisfaction; e-commerce market segmentation
Index Keywords: Cluster analysis; Electronic commerce; Information management; Regression analysis; Sales; Analysis method; Customer retention; Customer segmentation; Customer segments; Demographic factors; Market segmentation; Path analysis; Research results; Customer satisfaction

Title: Online groceries segmentation of brand, shopping convenience, and adoption to influence consumer purchase intention
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. K. H. Syahdan No. 9, Kemanggisan/Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; ABN Impact, Jl. Gaharu IV No. 10 Cilandak, South Jakarta, 12430, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gunawan, A., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. K. H. Syahdan No. 9, Kemanggisan/Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Saleha, R.A., ABN Impact, Jl. Gaharu IV No. 10 Cilandak, South Jakarta, 12430, Indonesia; Muchardie, B.G., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. K. H. Syahdan No. 9, Kemanggisan/Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The aim of this paper is to understand consumer online purchase intention of groceries. It examines how brand preference, shopping convenience, and adoption level influence purchase intention, and to identify market segmentation of online groceries in Jakarta; the three independent variables are used as segmentation basis. This is an associative-descriptive research based on a survey of 200 respondents in Jakarta. Data is analysed using linear regression and cluster analysis. The results show brand preference, shopping convenience, and consumer adoption level significantly influence purchase intention. Using these independent variables, this research categorised four groups of online shoppers in Jakarta that consist of trail blazer that can be approached by online brand community, socialiser that can be lured by utilising their purchasing data history to create personalised offering, assured achiever that can be reached through educating the market, and community traditionalist that can be approached using a pricing strategy. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: Adoption level; Brand preference market; Convenience; Online grocery shopping; Purchase intention; Segmentation
Funding Text 1: The purchase intention of customers can be associated with their adoption behavior toward the purchasing technology of grocery products. Preliminary data showed 26% of respondents agreed that technology that supports the system as well as sites/apps are an important factor to influence their online shopping. Interviews with marketing managers of online grocery stores in Jakarta revealed that the biggest challenge in influencing consumer shopping habits lies in educate consumers to switch from traditional grocery shopping at a supermarket to an online shopping system. It is easier to offer consumers who are tech-savvy or familiar with technology to adopt this new system. Nielsen (2015) stated the rank of market adoption varies, but until now the new e-commerce market was only able to tap into the tech-savvy. This finding was supported by Ahmed, Jamal, Ismail and Rezai (2013) who found rate of technology adoption attracts consumers to transact online. Srivastava, Chandra and Theng (2010) examined the level of consumer adoption, which is based on the phenomenon that consumer adoption of mobile payment solutions is low compared with traditional forms of payments. Irani, Dwivedi and Williams (2009) produced similar findings that despite broadband offering several benefits to consumers over its previous narrowband technology, many countries are still experiencing a low level of adoption.

Authors: Gunawan A., Indartoyo I.M., Muchardie B.G.
Title: Analysis of kids apparel market segmentation amongst millennial moms (an implication for kids apparel retailer in Jakarta)
Source title: Proceedings of the 27th International Business Information Management Association Conference - Innovation Management and Education Excellence Vision 2020: From Regional Development Sustainability to Global Economic Growth, IBIMA 2016
Affiliations: School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Binus Online Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gunawan, A., School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Indartoyo, I.M., School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Muchardie, B.G., Binus Online Learning, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Over the past 2 decades, Generation Y, which is often called Millennials, has become an important market segment. A phenomenon that emerged lately is the millennial moms are busy uploading photos of their children in such a way they dress through various social media like Facebook, Instagram, and Path. Although Millennials form a potential market segment, but Millennials is not a homogeneous group, so that millennial moms' shopping behavior can not be uniform due to the diversity of characteristics, both demographic and psychographic. To that end, it is important for marketers, especially kids apparel retailer, to divide this market into segments that are more specific, so that each segment can obtain a different treatment from marketers. The purpose of this study was to establish a kids apparel market segmentation based on the behavior of the millennial moms and determine whether there are differences in demographic characteristics between the segments formed, to eventually be able to provide recommendations for marketers of kids apparel retailer in Jakarta related to the differences in the character of the segments exist. Data was collected by survey method through questionnaires which are distributed to 306 people millennial moms in Jakarta. The analysis technique used is Cluster Analysis and Multiple Discriminant Analysis. Results from this study stated that there are 4 segments formed, namely shopping maniac moms, buy whatever moms, too much thinking moms, and reasonable choice-making moms, where there are significant differences in shopping behavior among the four segments. Copyright © 2016 International Business Information Management Association
Author Keywords: Kids apparel market segmentation; Millennial moms; Shopping behavior

Authors: Gunawan A., Diana B., Muchardie B.G., Sitinjak M.F.
Title: The effect of involvement and electronic word of mouth (eWOM) on brand image and its impact on consumers brand switching of mamypoko
Source title: International Journal of Economics and Management
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; PT Unicharm Indonesia, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gunawan, A., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Diana, B., PT Unicharm Indonesia, Jakarta, Indonesia; Muchardie, B.G., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sitinjak, M.F., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The main idea of this research is based on the phenomenon that a noticeable amount of MamyPoko consumers decided to switch brand after reading reviews, comments and information provided by other consumers on the Internet. The aim of this study is to determine the effect of involvement and electronic word of mouth (eWOM) on the brand image, and the impact toward Brand Switching on MamyPoko consumers through respondent's evaluation of each dimension. The study involved 100 active members on MamyPoko's official Facebook account. Data is collected by filling a questionnaire and is analyzed using the quantitative method, Path analysis. Based on the result of this research, it is known that involvement and eWOM partially and simultaneously affecting brand switching behavior through brand image. Therefore, Involvement, eWOM, and also Brand Image should be important variables to be concerned about in order to keep consumers from switching to other brands.
Author Keywords: Brand image; Brand switching; Consumer behavior; eWOM; Involvement
